entry.title: Combined summary - Annex Purpose Discussion: OP_ANNEX, Turing Completeness, and other considerations
entry.summary: The Bitcoin development mailing list has been discussing the Annex in Bitcoin, which is a way to include additional information in a transaction that can be analyzed immediately and unconditionally without knowing anything about the UTXO being spent. One potential use case of the annex is to optimize SIGHASH_GROUP, allowing a group of inputs to claim a group of outputs for signing. However, there are concerns about accessing individual entries from the annex rather than the annex as a single unit.It was suggested that a way of specifying locktimes in the annex could solve some problems with CLTV, but the general problem still exists. There is currently no need for padding to be specifiable at spend time, and any necessary padding can be added at the same time as the script. The idea of accessing previous or future transactions' annexes is discussed but deemed unlikely due to limitations in the utxo database and validation time.Despite these challenges, the annex has the potential to provide a more efficient and flexible way to include additional information on transactions. By reserving the annex now, new consensus rules can be immediately applied to utxos predating those rules without needing to update them on-chain first. Soft-fork solutions may be implemented to address any issues that arise. Overall, there needs to be further discussion regarding the purpose and constraints of the Annex before its use can be determined.Another discussion on the third-party malleability in Bitcoin transactions took place on the bitcoin-dev mailing list. It was pointed out that using the annex opcode for adding weight to a transaction does not require a signature and would make it third-party malleable. However, if a “valid” transaction has the minimum necessary Annex weight, then any malleated transaction with lower or higher Annex weight fails validation or cannot evict it from the mempool respectively.The bitcoin-dev mailing list has been exploring the use of an extra data item called checksigextra, which can be generalized and used for Eltoo by giving signatures an explicit extra seqnum. Another topic being discussed is the annex, which is a way to add extra data to a transaction that is analyzed immediately and unconditionally without knowing anything about the UTXO spent. The main advantage of using annex is to optimize SIGHASH_GROUP to allow a group of inputs to claim a group of outputs for signing. However, if script fragments require incompatible interpretations of the annex, a conflict may arise.To solve this problem, per-input by-height absolute locktimes can be specified as annex entry 3, and per-input by-time absolute locktimes as annex entry 4. It has been suggested to banish the OP_ANNEX opcode, which is an unassigned opcode reserved for future use. Accessing the annex through script does not make sense at this time, but it can be used to enforce new consensus rules in the future without needing to evaluate any scripts.It was concluded in taproot review meetings that there needs to be a simple way of encoding entries into the annex, and a tag/length/value scheme like lightning uses could be implemented. In cases where cross-input signature aggregation is used, agreement on the message being signed must be established beforehand, and therefore the annex cannot be delayed until after signing. Lastly, it is noted that signatures pay for themselves, as every signature is 64 or 65 bytes but only has 50 units of validation weight.
